title: LInC Lab
text:
If you are interested in joining the lab as a graduate or undergraduate student, please reach out to Rachel Ryskin directly.

E-mail
linc.lab.ucmerced@gmail.com


Address
University of California, Merced  SSM 122  5200 Lake Road  Merced, CA 95343

title: Rachel Ryskin
text: Rachel Ryskin is an Assistant Professor of Cognitive & Information Sciences at UC Merced. She wants to figure out what cognitive processes and computations enable humans to understand each other. In particular, she studies how learning and context-specific predictions help the human mind and brain deal with the noise and ambiguity present in everyday communication.

title: Rachel Ryskin
text:
Education
Massachusetts Institute of Technology  Postdoc in Brain & Cognitive Sciences | 2016-2020
University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign  PhD in Cognitive Psychology | 2010-2016
Northwestern University  B.A in Cognitive Science | 2006-2010

title: Language, Interaction, & Cognition Lab
text:
Language endows us with the ability to communicate the contents of our mind with another person. But how do we decode another person’s thoughts and intentions from a sequence of sounds (speech) or shapes (letters, signs)? This challenge seems compounded by the fact that transmission of this sequence is often imperfect – speakers and listeners make errors, don’t have the same prior knowledge, and sometimes even see different things. Yet, communication with another person typically feels effortless. In the Language, Interaction, & Cognition (LInC) Lab, we take a cognitive science approach to understanding how the human language processing system extracts meaning from uncertain and variable input.
To get more information about ongoing projects, please visit the research page or check individual lab members’ pages for a full list of their publications. If you would like to participate in the lab’s research or are interested in joining the lab, get in touch via e-mail.

title: Open Positions
text:
Please send your CV and answers to the below questions to linc.lab.ucmerced@gmail.com. Please send these in the format “Lastname_CV.pdf” and “Lastname_application.pdf” in an email with the subject line, “Lastname Lab Manager Position 2024”.

Please provide the following information:

Telephone
Email
Current city of residence
Undergraduate institution
Undergraduate major(s)
Cumulative GPA
Year of graduation or expected graduation
Are you eligible to work in the US? (unfortunately, we are unable to sponsor new work visas for international applicants)

What experience do you have with empirical research? On what kind of studies did you work (e.g., mTurk, laboratory studies, neuroimaging studies, analysis of big datasets, other)? In what way(s) were you involved in this work (e.g., did you design the study, schedule and run participants, analyze data, program the experiment, etc.)?
Please comment on your programming and technical expertise. What programming languages have you used (e.g., Matlab, Python, Bash, HTML/CSS, Javascript, PHP, MySQL)? Could you program an experiment, for example, in PsychoPy, Psychtoolbox, or another software package? Do you have any experience with database development/management? Have you worked with machine learning or NLP methods?
Please comment on your statistical expertise. What kinds of analyses are you comfortable implementing? What statistical analysis packages do you have experience with (e.g. SPSS, R, etc.)? Do you have any experience with computational modeling?
What are your long-term goals? How will this job help you reach those goals?
How long do you plan to stay in this job?
In this job, you would be involved in many different kinds of tasks that differ in the skills that they demand. No one is likely to have all these skills on the first day of the job, which is fine; that’s what learning is for. Here are some descriptions of different tasks, demands, and skills that the job will sometimes require. Please rank-order these from those that you are most to least comfortable with:

Attention to detail
Writing
Programming
Tolerance for sometimes repetitive work
Interacting with other people
Managing other people
Organizing large quantities of information
Independence (e.g., the ability to figure something hard out on your own)
Working against a deadline

Which research project from the lab are you most interested in exploring and why?
If you are able to share links to any examples of your technical work (e.g. on GitHub or a personal website) please include them here.
Please provide the contact information for at least two individuals who could be asked for a recommendation and indicate in what capacity you have worked with them, and for how long.
